Situation1: They notice dust and mess building up and carry out more regular cleaning tasks.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: I glanced at the clock as I scrubbed the kitchen floor, sweat beading on my forehead. The dust had been piling up all week, and I knew the supervisor expected every corner to shine. I could already hear her voice in my head, reminding me that a spotless house was the mark of a good cleaner. But as I wiped down the last counter, my phone buzzed—a reminder for my volunteer shift. I was the only one scheduled to unlock the community center this morning, and people would already be waiting outside, hoping to get in on time. My heart pounded. If I left now, the house wouldn’t be as clean as it should be, and I’d risk disappointing my boss. But if I stayed to finish, I’d be late opening the center, letting down the people counting on me. I stood frozen, mop in hand, torn between the demands of my job and my commitment to the community.
